bug.short_desc: Modify MultipleFilesReader to improve Sensor performance

long_desc.thetext: MultipleFilesReader is used for every adapter executed by GLA. This class currently assumes the filename is a regular expression and therefore tries to match it against every file in the directory. This regex matching is unnecessary if the filname is not a regular expression. In the init() method, the filename should be tested first to see if exists in the directory. Only if it doesn't exist should the regex matching be attempted.
This should be fixed in 4.3
Targetting to iteration 2
Committed fix to MultipleFilesReader to TPTP Head CVS.

bug.short_desc: Overriding display of custom categories and process elements in configuration views

long_desc.thetext: It would be nice if one could override the hierarchy of the custom categories and their related process elements when defining the views for a configuration. In the latest OpenUP build (20060714), the phases and milestones were physically removed from the delivery process to remove a level of hierarchy when rendered in the tree view. It would be nice if one could adjust how process elements are rendered in the views without having to change the process structure. Perhaps one can already do this by taking a different approach to setting up the custom categories and their assigned elements in the first place.

bug.short_desc: [Web Help] documentation on Profile On Server feature

long_desc.thetext: There is no detail documentation on how TPTP-WTP integration Profile on Server feature in TPTP packaging. A help doc should be created to help user setup and profile web application.
Has anything been done on this? Adjust the target milestone appropriately.

There is help content covering profile on server feature in TPTP package; however, there is no online help yet on setup of profiling on server feature.
I will create one and post it online by release of 4.3
Retarget to 4.4.i1, not a 4.3 exit criteria. pending peer review.

bug.short_desc: Unable to delete existing files when publishing new configuration

long_desc.thetext: In certain circumstance (which I have been unable to diagnose), when publishing a configuration that should overwrite the previously published version, I get the following error message: "IUPP0101E: The selected configuration cannot be published. Reason: The destination path...contains files that cannot be deleted...". If I close all browser windows, this still happens (although it took care of it in some instances). It appears that shutting down EPF Composer and restarting takes care of it (which it would seem one shouldn't have to resort to).
It cannot be reproduced.
It cannot be reproduced.
np,closed.

The issue is that when you publish using the applet, and the applet is loaded by IE, then the corresponding files will be locked by the IE. Until you closed all the IE, you won't be able to delete the folder. Note: you also have to close all the EPF editors as those rich text editors have embedded IE too.

long_desc.thetext: When publishing work product dependency diagrams, the rendered diagram is right-justified on the page, when it would seem that it should be left-justified.

bug.short_desc: The error annotations aren't refreshed if I have two code panes open

long_desc.thetext: When I do a quick fix, I expect the red badge of alarm to promptly fade away. But now that I am working in a two-code-pane mode, that doesn't happen. I have my test class in one pane and my tested class below it; I write a test that requires a new method in the tested class, hit ctrl-1, and it puts the new method where I want it. But the red squiggle that tells me the tested class has no such method, the red dot beside the scroll bar, and the red icon in the left margin are all still present and remain until I close and re-open the class.

>I am working in a two-code-pane mode, What's this? If you mean two Java editors side by side then what you see is expected: for performance reasons we don't refresh inactive editors.
I verified in R3.2 that the error goes away once the editor where the error is still shown get the focus.

bug.short_desc: [Presentations] Facility to disable tab close hotspots pre tabfolder group basis per perspective

long_desc.thetext:
One of my pet peaves with using Eclipse for development is with the standard Java perspective the bottom right hand group of tab which usualy has things like Problems view in it, accidentially clicking the close tab hotspot which exists on each tab that is in focus, because the tabs are so small and change size / move around when in focus this happens a few times per day for me.
But I wish to keep the close tab facility on each tab for my editors.
So this feature request is to allow the right click action on any tab in the tab group to have a toggle button action on it to enable/disable per-tab close buttons.
I can still close tabs by using the right-click Close action if I need to. But this would allow the perspective user to disable the per-tab close buttons for in the bottom right hand group only and retain the per-tab close buttons for all the other views.
This preferences should be saved along with the general tabgroup information when eclipse is restarted.
The problem wouldn't be so bad for me if the tabs didn't change size and jump around between focus changes. This is essentially the reason why I hit the wrong part of the tab so often with the mouse which makes it a real PITA.
I am usually either waiting for the Eclipse UI to catch up with me or the views in the lower right handside at set to automatically come into focus when new data arrives. Like on the console view.
Possibily related bugs:
https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=58982 https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=126545

bug.short_desc: [jobs] Provide means to start user-job in background

long_desc.thetext:
The docs say nothing about this: http://help.eclipse.org/help31/index.jsp?topic=/org.eclipse.platform.doc.isv/guide/runtime_jobs.htm
It seems like it would be a good idea (anyway, I have a user-requirement) that a user-job (i.e., one that users know about and can cancel) could be *started* in background (i.e., just showing up in the progress-monitor [or whatever it is called] in the statusline).
This is controlled by the "Always run in background" preference. If you want the job to start in the background regardless of that preference, then don't make it a user job.

(In reply to comment #1) > This is controlled by the "Always run in background" preference. > OK, I'll look into getting that preference set in my RCP app -- that would be IPreferenceConstants.RUN_IN_BACKGROUND? And once that is set will there be a way to force certain other jobs to run in foreground? (I can make those jobs be of a different family if that would help.)
> If you want > the job to start in the background regardless of that preference, then don't > make it a user job. > Well, that might seem to make sense (and I myself think it should be a system job); but my users want (A) that the job be visible and cancelable (e.g., by clicking on the 'progress-bar' in the status-line that is made visible by calling configurer.setShowProgressIndicator(true) in WorkbenchWindowAdvisor); AND (B) that it not appear in a modal dialog as soon as it is launched.
So I thought "user Job, but start in background". Seems like "start this Job in fg/bg" could be some kind of setting on the Job, or a parameter to schedule(), or ...

What you're asking for sounds like the default behaviour if the job is neither a user job nor the a system job. It will show progress in the status line, and not in a dialog. Note there are actually two progress regions in the status line - one for showing progress on blocking work (for example used by editor save), and another for showing progress of jobs.
I'm not sure... I know you at least need the status line to be visible (getShowStatusLine(true)). Closing, as there doesn't appear to be a bug or enhancement request here.

bug.short_desc: Detailed formater does not seem to recognize methods of the current class

long_desc.thetext:
The error only occurs on 5.0 and 6.0 VMs (both Sun and IBM), not 1.4.2 VMs.
It could have something to do with the definition created by the evaluation code being slightly different in later VMs to allow for enumerations.
Set<K> keySet() Set<Map.Entry<K,V>> entrySet() Syntax error, type parameters are only available if source level is 5.0
Requires further investigation.
Needs investigation

Only occurs under the following circumstances:
1) Must be using a 5.0 VM or higher that allows type parameters. 2) Must have compiler compliance to 1.4 or earlier (disallowing type parameters). 3) Detail formatter must work with a class that uses type parameters (such as Map, HashMap, etc).
At least 100 errors are generated during creation of the compiled expression. Some examples:
Pb(590) Syntax error, type parameters are only available if source level is 5.0, Pb(2) K cannot be resolved to a type, Pb(593) Syntax error, parameterized types are only available if source level is 5.0, Pb(2) V cannot be resolved to a type, Pb(593) Syntax error, parameterized types are only available if source level is 5.0, Pb(2) K cannot be resolved to a type, Pb(2) V cannot be resolved to a type, Pb(100) The method keySet() is undefined for the type HashMap, Pb(100) The method get(Object) is undefined for the type HashMap, Pb(105) Void methods cannot return a value
There is a conflict during evaluation. The source obtained for HashMap is from 1.5 and contains type parameters, but type parameters are restricted by the compiler compliance.
I do not know how to fix this. The evaluation engine needs to be able to evaluate 1.4 code with a 1.5 VM. Will discuss with Darin.

Created an attachment (id=64962) work in progress
Our "source generator" generates source from the source code found in the project (in this case, 1.5 or 1.6 source for HashMap, which happens to be the JRE bound to the project). However, the compliance options are 1.4, so the source does not compile. This is a start at generating source without 1.5 source features based on the projects source level setting, rather than the source found in the libs.
Fixed in BinaryBasedSourceGenerator and SourceBasedSourceGenerator. We only add generics/parameterized type info based on the compiler source level of the project.
Please verify, Curtis.
Verified

bug.short_desc: [launcher] Eclipse on Mac OSX should have a 'Restart -clean' option on the Dock Icon menu

long_desc.thetext: Using the -clean option on the Mac is too hard. Either you modify eclipse.ini to include -clean always, or you have to revert to the command line. Many application offer extra options on the dock icon popup menu. Is it possible to have Eclipse add the -clean option to the dock icon?
This is interesting however I'm afraid that if we start adding this option we end up opening a pandora box and have to add all the options and even more.

(In reply to comment #1) > This is interesting however I'm afraid that if we start adding this option we > end up opening a pandora box and have to add all the options and even more. When I have done updates and Eclipse offers to restart, is that a Restart -clean?
Maybe there should be a "Restart -clean" just above the File/Exit menu on every platform...
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: [refactoring] [dcr] IDE should automatically suggest possible refactorings

long_desc.thetext:
Interesting ideas.
I don't think the IDE can find out that two calls are redudant, except we have the possibility to declare that the returning object of new File(target) is equals to an other call to new File(target) To be able to suggest to use extract method to avoid duplicated code, it has to know that calls to 'loadDirectoryStructureFlat' don't have side effects and are not depending on the context.
Thats all knowledge that programmers somehow know.
Maybe some extensive static analisys on the code with custom rules could help. Would be nice to have to external (research) project work on this, but I don't see anything that we could offer.

Of course, their may be side effects, therefore the IDE must not refactor automatically. It should only suggest some possible refactorings it detects.
Perhaps a modular approach makes sense. There is a "base feature" that allows hooks. And anybody can develop those hooks that are simple or complex detection mechanisms that suggest one or more refactorings.
But maybe that it is too complex, don't really know.
Best regards
Thorsten van Ellen

What is the technical difference to editor hints like * "The local variable abc is never read" * "Type safety: The expression of type HashSet need unchecked conversion to conform to Set<ABC>" * "The import a.b.C is never used" and some repair suggestions? Only the "recognition" code/algorithm!?
One could iterate over all existing refactorings and think about reasonable szenarios like the one showed.
E.g. think about extracting variables. When do you extract variables? * When expression code is redundant. * When evaluation takes much time and redundant execution is too expensive. * When you want to explain a expression by the variable name. * ...?
When do you extract methods? * When snippets are redundant. * When snippets/side effects must be executed again (extract method in opposite to extract variable: only one calculation)
When do you inline methods? * When you want to optimize performance, e.g. in deep nested loops. * ...
When do you ...
O.k. some of these patterns are perhaps too * complex to decide, e.g. when is an expression too expensive? * numerous to suggest, e.g. suggesting variable extraction for every expression to explain those expression by a variable name is bothering.
But some of these patterns maybe easy, e.g. redundant expression code or perhaps even redundant snippets, that may be extracted as method and parametrized.
Best regards
Thorsten

long_desc.thetext: It might be a bug in Link, RowLayout or computeSize(). In any case, we'll need a stand alone snippet that shows the problem or a set of steps in Eclipse.

bug.short_desc: New Process for IP Submmissions ( Contribution Questionnaires)

long_desc.thetext:
The EMO would like to propose a new procedure to make it simpler and easier for committers to track the process by which Contribution Questionnaires are reviewed and approved.
The current process is lacking transparency.
Please see http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/IPzilla

The proposed process is great. A couple of comments: 1. Can we set up IPZilla so that the project lead or a mailing-list for a project will be automatically cc-ed when a request is submitted from that project? 2. If the submission involves changing the original third party source code, shall we require to submit both the original and the revised source code?

good deal. are we attaching source or binary or both? Generally speaking it is easy for teams to identify the binary they want. Relating that back to the source is sometimes easy but can be a challenge. What will be the process there?

(In reply to comment #2) > good deal. are we attaching source or binary or both? Generally speaking it > is easy for teams to identify the binary they want. Relating that back to the > source is sometimes easy but can be a challenge. What will be the process > there? >
We would need the source related to the binary code that the project intends to use. Currently, the tools that we use for due diligence only effectively review source files. From the standpoint of accuracy, I believe the teams would be in the best position to properly identify the source related to the binary they intend to use.

Sounds good!
What does the Severity field of an IPzilla request mean? Does it indicate priority in the view of the reporter (in contrast to the Priority field which is the priority for the assignee)? It could also be used to separate large from small contributions, e.g. - new stuff - minor version update - major version upgrade

(In reply to comment #2) > good deal. are we attaching source or binary or both? Generally speaking it > is easy for teams to identify the binary they want. Relating that back to the > source is sometimes easy but can be a challenge. What will be the process > there? >
I would like to reinforce what Janet said on this. I understand that it is a hassle for projects to figure where the source is. But given the limited resources available at the hub (e.g. EMO), it just does not scale to have us go looking for the source.
The other point of course is that the projects are much more qualified to identify the relevant source than we are.

(In reply to comment #4) > What does the Severity field of an IPzilla request mean?
Good point. I have no idea.
Anyone out there have some strong feelings on how to best use the severity field?

(In reply to comment #1) > The proposed process is great. A couple of comments: > 1. Can we set up IPZilla so that the project lead or a mailing-list for a > project will be automatically cc-ed when a request is submitted from that > project?
I could imagine setting up components in IPzilla for each PMC and using that to send emails to the corresponding PMC list.
> 2. If the submission involves changing the original third party source code, > shall we require to submit both the original and the revised source code?
I'm not sure I get this one? It's actually news to me that we're hacking other project's code at Eclipse.
But in general, the whole point of the IP process is to scrub the code that we are distributing. That is the guiding principle. Always submit the code that we are going to be shipping.
The corollary to this is to please only submit the pieces of code that the project plans to ship. There have been several instances where we have spent a lot of time scanning and analyzing chunks of code that the projects had no intention of actually shipping because (for example) the CQ pointed us to an entire project rather than just the JARs that were going to be distributed.

+1 for the general concept. We never knew that status of our requests.
It would be great if we added an element of self-service. For example, how about setting up an automatic scanning server. You upload code to it and get back an IP scan that identifiers suspect keywords. This would be a first pass and let contributors resolve the most obvious problems. The scan could also check for copied code or other problem areas. The server would be access protected to committers only to avoid abuse or DOS attacks.

(In reply to comment #8) > +1 for the general concept. We never knew that status of our requests. > > It would be great if we added an element of self-service. For example, how > about setting up an automatic scanning server. You upload code to it and get > back an IP scan that identifiers suspect keywords. This would be a first pass > and let contributors resolve the most obvious problems.
Definitely a worthy idea for a future enhancement.

+ 1 It is wonderful that you are doing this. - Knowing that Eclipse currently has 113 contributions in the queue helps put things in perspective. -The transparancy this provides will greatly help with planning - CC'ing the project lead is also appreciated. -The initiative to give more visibility to the frequently used pieces of open source code that have already been approved by Eclipse will make it easier for projects to only send the PMC the code that needs to be approved (and we won't waste time obtaining source for things that you have already approved.) - As your processes continue to evolve please continue to keep the community updated in how we can best make the process as easy as possible for you. - One of the most difficult things about getting contributions approved is not knowing when they will be approved. While I appreciate that it is very difficult to estimate how long each request will take to process, any information you can provide such as position an item is in the queue or current queue length will be helpful. Perhaps severity could be used to rate the impact on the project (i.e workaound exists, critial path for project after date X etc.)

+1 This is a *great* way to add much needed transparency.
ATTRIBUTES: I have been using a Bugzilla for generic task management (i.e. not code) and here are thoughts on attributes, including others' ideas above: * Severity: used by the submitter to indicate how critical this is to the project * Priority: used by reviewers/assignee to indicate where this is in their queue * Target milestone: could be used for month/quarter that this is scheduled for in order to make it clear when reviews are slipping * Status & Resolution: the defaults could be good enough, proposed customization seems marginally better * other: get rid of Hardware, OS, Version and QA Contact, they're meaningless and annoying
SELF-SERVICE: I strongly support Arthur's decentralization idea. I don't know what the foundation is using but for this year's Jolts I reviewed ProtexIP/development by Black Duck, a slick app that seems possible to set up in the way Arthur is suggesting.
CUSTOMIZATION: Whatever the changes to Bugzilla, I highly recommend not forking the code base so that IPzilla can be migrated to Bugzilla 3.0 and future versions. Otherwise eclipse.org will be on the hook for critical updates, security patches, etc.
AUTHENTICATION: For similar requirements we use htpasswd and an ssl certificate. We also have an access list per-Product. These can't be made per-Component, so consider setting up products according to the desired access control.
Fyi, I don't foresee any problems with the Mylar rich client to Bugzilla supporting IPzilla, in case others are interested in using it for this purpose.

(In reply to comment #10 and #11) > +1
Thanks for all the great feedback.

+1 and many thanks for this proposal. The projects in DSDP are excited about this.
One thing Janet talked about in a recent council meeting was distinguishing between difficulty of the contribution review, for example:
1. The contribution is entirely from a member company's commerical product, so it should be a quick process when we get to it in the queue. (There are other examples of this, too.)
2. The contribution comes from another open source product, has cryptography, has a new OSS license that the foundation hasn't seen, has an unknown pedigree, etc. This contribution will take a long time to review, and has a chance of rejection.
So it would be nice to categorize the contribution using a field in IPzilla. This helps determine the risk in depending on the contribution for a particular release. Thoughts? Perhaps Janet can comment on what's easy vs. what's hard.

All,
We've updated the proposal at http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/IPzilla to reflect what we expect to get done by the end of September.
Comments welcomed!
Thanks for everyone's comments so far. Seems like everyone is pretty enthusiastic about this concept.

(In reply to comment #13) > One thing Janet talked about in a recent council meeting was distinguishing > between difficulty of the contribution review
Doug,
In the examples you gave, I would think that #1 would likely be a contribution under the EPL while #2 is clearly not. I think that's really the clear differentiator that everyone should know about and be thinking about when they complete a CQ.

Thanks Mike. On further clarification on EPL contributions, though. Code that is EPL but comes from outside the Eclipse infrastructure (perhaps on sourceforge or another venue) is subject to the more rigorous due diligence process, since the pedigree of all contributions to that code must be established.
So, project leads should not assume that _any_ EPL code will get through the process quickly. This is why I made the distinction of code coming from a contributing company in comment #13.

(In reply to comment #16)
Doug,
Yes, you are completely right. We definitely scan and review code coming from a single source (e.g. a member company) under the EPL. I didn't mean to imply otherwise. However, historically those types of submissions are less problematic than the other types. As a result they are typically dealt with faster.
Given that IPZilla exists, should this bug be RESOLVED/FIXED?

(In reply to comment #18) > Given that IPZilla exists, should this bug be RESOLVED/FIXED? >
+1. the process works for me.
Closing as fixed.

bug.short_desc: Monitoring not starting automatically when checkbox enabled

long_desc.thetext:
1) Select application to profile on a server 2) Profile As -> Profile... 3) Set up configuration for server 4) Select Monitor Tab 5) Double Click on Java Applications 6) Next 7) Ensure the 'Automatically start monitoring when application is launched' checbox is checked 8) Select profile 9) Pop-up will tell you to make sure you start monitoring 10) If you do not manually start monitoring, it will not start
Notes: I was using JBoss 4.04 and a web application to produce this error. It does automatically start when I profile a regular Java application (not on the Server).
This bug is happening in all attach scenarios.

I have fixed this for the PI agent. Automatically monitoring an agent is an operation that is specific to each agent and needs to be handled in the attach delegate registered for each agent. Eugene, you may need to do some work to get this working for profile on server. See PIAttachLauncherDelegate in trace.ui on how the PI attach delegate handles the auto monitor.

the attach option is supported in Profile on Server configuration.

bug.short_desc: New Feature: providers for colours and fonts, etc on nodes and connections.

long_desc.thetext: Users should be able to define what colors, fonts, etc, should be used for individual nodes and arcs.

Created an attachment (id=46667) A patch to address this issue.
This patch includes many changes to Zest core, which address the problem. Changes in this patch will probably break applications using previous versions of Zest. Changes include:
1) ZestStyles has been refactored. - Layout-related styles have been removed. Users must apply a layout to views in order to use layouts. Default layout is always a grid layout. - styles have been grouped to by scope: Connection-related styles begin with the word CONNECTION. Node (entity) related styles begin with the word NODE. All other styles have no special signifier. - Views and implementations that had a dependancy on the old ZestStyles have been changed.
2) ZestException has been added to support errors that may occur when people are setting styles. ZestPlugin.error() has been added to make usage of ZestException easy.
3) new package: org.eclipse.mylar.zest.core.internal.messages. -added to support internationalization of strings, especially in error messages. ZestException uses the messages here by default.
4) New class org.eclipse.mylar.zest.core.viewers.AbstractStructuredGraphViewer -this is now the parent for all graph viewers. Used to support setting of default style values for connections and nodes within a graph.
5) Styles for connections and for nodes can be set graph-wide or on an individual node/connection basis. This is made possible by: a)AbstractStructuredGraphViewer.setConnectionStyle/NodeStyle. b)new label provider extensions: IConnectionStyleProvider, IEntityConnectionStyleProvider, IEntityStyleProvider. Implement these on the provided label providers to allow for node/connection specific styles. c)new class: org.eclipse.mylar.zest.core.internal.graphmodel.GraphItemStyler which checks and sets styles on individual nodes/connections by making call-backs to the given style providers. d) related changes in GraphModelFactory and GraphModelEntityFactory to make calls to GraphItemStyler as the items are being created on the graph. All styling of graph items should be centralized in GraphItemStyler. e) new class: org.eclipse.mylar.zest.core.internal.graphmodel.IZestGraphDefaults supplies default styles for arcs/nodes.
5) This patch also addresses bug 151332 by creating the new class IZestColorConstants and adding the getColor() method to ZestPlugin. Colors are all now retrieved from the central color registry. They aren't created by individual items. This insures that they will be properly disposed.
patch is in head.
Patch is in head

bug.short_desc: Add an action to bugzilla editor to open issue by id taken from selected text

long_desc.thetext: Add an action to bugzilla editor to isse taking id from selected text. So, when link decorator don't recognize issues it would be possible to open them anyways. Select issue id in text and use action from popup menu to open it.

I wonder if instead we should have an Open Task dialog that let's you put in an ID, and opens from the server if the ID is not in the Task List. This could make for a bit of UI redundancy though. For example, if there are no matches for an ID we could make the filtered tree show a node that says "click here to query server".

Mik, the most of the time for me those ids won't be in the task list. Primarily because I am too often open issues from history or sync view. So, I'd really prefer to query server right away.
PS: that could be similar to AnyEdit plugin that is opening resources, and in case if there are more then one hit it offers a choise.

bug.short_desc: parser does not handle MacOS 9 line delimiters

long_desc.thetext:
When C/C++ files -- which otherwise parse correctly -- exist in or are converted to MacOS 9 line delimiter ('\r') format, the parser fails to parse them. I've seen this both at the UI level (the outline goes empty) and at the CModel and DOM API levels. BaseScanner seems to only recognize '\n' or '\r\n' as line terminators.
Not, of course, that I see a lot of people will use this delimiter style, but the core platform provides it via "File / Convert line delimiters to..." and "Prefs / General / Editors / New text file default delimiter", so CDT should be able to handle it, or fail gracefully.

bug.short_desc: Browser not supported on linux ppc

long_desc.thetext: This has been the case because the swt mozilla libraries have not been built on ppc. This omission was a result of not having a ppc-compiled mozilla available to build against.
fixed in HEAD > 0720

bug.short_desc: wrong error message on adding memory monitor
org.eclipse.mylar.zest.core.ZestColors doesn't follow Eclipse best practices.

long_desc.thetext: Consider using a Color registry instead.

The patch for 151327 also addresses bug 151332 by creating the new class IZestColorConstants and adding the getColor() method to ZestPlugin. Colors are all now retrieved from the central color registry. They aren't created by individual items. This insures that they will be properly disposed.
Patch from bug #151327 address this issue. I am closing this bug.

bug.short_desc: Generated editpartProvider extension leaks plug-ins

long_desc.thetext:
I am not sure if this has been fixed since I haven't used the generator in a while, but last time I used it, the generated editpartProvider extension didn't generate the <object> or <context> elements. Which means, by default, all such plug-ins get activated when any GMF editor is opened.
While the generation should be fixed, I think it's better to make the object and context elements required. That will let GMF clients know that that's important, whether the code is generated or not. Otherwise, plug-ins will continue to leak without the developers knowing it. Once I found out about this, I looked at a bunch of different GMF editors and found that almost all of them had this problem, including the TaiPan editor example. Only the logic example plug-in wasn't leaking.
Decreasing severity. Plug-in activation doesn't sound as a major memory leak.
I would have to agree this doesn't sound like a memory leak at all. But it is a performance problem and it is contrary to the typical usage of extension points, being to avoid activation.
Related request: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=149328
Need to address this and other perfomance issues during 2.1 cycle.

Then DnD a CP, for example 'cots_project_management_discipline'. 3.In the prompt for bringing all descriptors, select 'NO'. 4.Change configuration to yours, then check the configuration explorer, 'cots_project_management_discipline' CP is not there. 5.Check your configuration editor, it is not updated with COTS CP.
For copy it won't update configuration like the way it does for 'extend'.

----snippet from www.eclipse.org/tptp----
There are two scenarios covered by this function:
1. The classes you want to collect line level coverage are available in the workspace. (For example, you run a set of JUnit testcases and you want to get line coverage for the code you execute.) The feature covering this scenario can be downloaded from here. The code coverage can be initiated during a run of a launch configuration by selecting the Engage Code Coverage option in the Package Explorer view. In this case, while the application is running, line coverage is registered and then reported at the end of the application. The classes for which line coverage is reported should be in the workspace. Note: To collect line coverage, you only need the two plugins provided by the feature above. This feature does not depend on any other TPTP plugins and it does not require the Agent Controller technology.

Can you try launch Eclipse with a new workspace, open Profile and Logging prespective, and check if there is any .log file created under workspace/.metadata folder?

bug.short_desc: 3.2 Debugger Hesitating

long_desc.thetext:
Since installing 3.2, I've had a few problems with the debugger. This problem is the most annoying but I can't reproduce a specific scenario to demonstrate it.
I connect to an external application (JBoss) and get to a breakpoint. I'm stepping through some code when, at some point, the stepping process seems to hesitate, at least from the perspective of the debugger display. The step over button gets disabled and the next statement is not highlighted. If I click on the top stack trace element, I get everything back. So, at some point during some debugging sessions, I have to press the step-over button, then click on the stack, for each statement I want to step over. If I resume and reach the same starting breakpoint again, everything works properly again, and that may continue until some later debug session, when I get the problem again.
I don't know if this is related but one of the other problems is that disconnecting from the external application doesn't always reset the debugger thread view and it appears that I'm still connected to the application. As soon as I touch the scroll bar, in that pane, it resets the display as expected.

When it happened again recently, it was after a fairly lengthy delay, when I had to step away during a debugging session. I don't know if there is a set delay period after which it goes bad but I think it may often happen after long delays.
Just to put another twist on that other, possibly related problem, after pressing "Resume", whilst the debugger was showing hesitation, did resume the program but the display didn't refresh until I hit the scroll bar. Until then, I could click on stack elements and would be taken to the relevant class. As soon as I hit the scroll bar, the display collapsed as originally expected.

We have had several fixes related to the described problems released to the 3.2.1 maintenance stream. It would be helpful if you could use the latest maintenance build to see what problems (if any) remain.
Please see the following bugs that have been fixed, and sound similar: bug 140561, bug 143805, bug 149728, bug 150193

I also encounted the similar issue. When I use Remote Java Application option to debug j2ee application, the speed is very slow. e.g. In debuging mode, press F6, it will spend much time to step to next line and sometime it will no any response and I can not stop the debug after I click Terminate icon.

I also encounted the similar issue. When I use Remote Java Application option to debug j2ee application, the speed is very slow. e.g. In debuging mode, press F6, it will spend much time to step to next line and sometime it will no any response and I can not stop the debug after I click Terminate icon. But in Eclipse 3.1.1, it has no above issue.
Pan, have you tried the 3.2.1 maintenance build?
I have tried the 3.2.1 maintenance build, it seems more quickly than 3.2GA.
I tried the 3.2.1 build but had some problems with launching the MyEclipse JSP designer. As I needed that, I had to switch back to the GA build. I'll try again, when I get a chance.

bug.short_desc: Add hook to kick VCS repository syncronization on incoming tasks

long_desc.thetext:
It could be a really handy optimization to kick repository suncronization based on the new incoming tasks (Bugzilla, Jira, etc).
Genrally querying issue tracking system is faster then running VCS sync against many projects. And since task information already there and it allows to retrieve contextual data (e.g. affected projects, etc) it could allow to narrow down syncronization scope and kick synchronization only for affected projects, which should speed up VCS syncranization.
Neat idea. I guess that the most obvious trigger would be task activation?
Task activation would definetely ensure that code is up to date. Though I was thinking about query synchroniation.

Below is the stack - !ENTRY org.eclipse.core.jobs 4 2 2006-07-21 14:41:57.013 !MESSAGE An internal error occurred during: "Periodic workspace save.". !STACK 0 java.lang.NullPointerExceptionnull at java.io.Writer.write(Unknown Source)null at java.io.BufferedWriter.newLine(Unknown Source)null at java.util.Properties.writeln(Unknown Source)null at java.util.Properties.store(Unknown Source)null at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.saveMasterTable(SaveManager.java:1049)null at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.saveMasterTable(SaveManager.java:1040)null at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.SaveManager.save(SaveManager.java:1017)null at org.eclipse.core.internal.resources.DelayedSnapshotJob.run(DelayedSnapshotJob.java:44)null at org.eclipse.core.internal.jobs.Worker.run(Worker.java:58)null

bug.short_desc: Constant JVM crashes using Eclipse 3.2 on Linux

long_desc.thetext: We have an application we've been building on Eclipse 3.2. We've been continually testing on RHEL 4 throughout the project. Recently we updated to the release version of Eclipse 3.2 from the M6 build. Since then we get frequent JVM crashes in our software. We're using the SWT_AWT bring to host Swing components and I *think* that the crashes are related. This problem is also appearing on SUSE 10. I've attached the dump log.
Created an attachment (id=46611) Crash log

Interestingly, this newsgroup thread seems to have an extremely similar looking stack trace ...
http://dev.eclipse.org/newslists/news.eclipse.platform.swt/msg24062.html

Continued investigation ... I the actual dying behaviour here is a duplicate of https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=113342, which I think is the follow up bug from the thread I mentioned in my last note ... Looks like a disposed font is being used. I don't think I want to mark this issue as dup though since:
1) My code that's dying isn't doing anything with fonts (explicitly anyway, maybe draw2d is doing something funny?) 2) This used to work in M6 and then stopped in 3.2 ... we didn't make any code changes on our end.
_AND_
Nix the comment on this possibly being related to SWT_AWT ... I can repro it without ever hitting code that uses SWT_AWT.

Yet more investigation ... this problem is probably in the libcairo-swt.so that is included with 3.2 install (not much of shocker given the stack trace). If I remove the .so file Eclipse runs fine for me on SUSE 10 :) ... I haven't tried it myself, but I've been told that this doesn't help RHEL 4 (though it may have it's own messed up version of libcairo installed). I should also mention that I've never had this problem on my Ubuntu 6.06 machine which aparently has an working version of libcairo :)
Despite what I said earlier, this was reproducible with 3.2 M6 ... but not M4 (sorry I got my milestones mixed up).
As a work around I can disable the portions of my code that are forcing libcairo to be loaded at all on Linux. That's not so great because our Linux customers won't be getting the same groovy semi-transparent look and feel that our Windows customers will. Seems wrong.

Sorry Josh, this bug fell through the cracks. Sorry about that. You've done a bunch of good reseach.
The libcairo-swt.so that is shipped with SWT is supposed to be loaded only when cairo is not already installed. Could this code be failing?
Bogdan and SSQ, here is the top of the stack:
j org.eclipse.swt.internal.gtk.OS.strlen(I)I+0 j org.eclipse.swt.graphics.GC.setCairoFont(
It looks like the string that is being passed into strlen() is bad.
It looks like a Font that is still set in the GC has been disposed.

!SESSION 2006-07-20 23:31:45.532 ----------------------------------------------- eclipse.buildId=M20060629-1905 java.version=1.5.0_07 java.vendor=Sun Microsystems Inc. BootLoader constants: OS=linux, ARCH=x86_64, WS=gtk, NL=en_US Command-line arguments: -os linux -ws gtk -arch x86_64 -clean

Created an attachment (id=46613) JVM Thread Dump

Worker-0 is waiting for the Main thread to release its lock 0x00002b2abb64c808.
But the Main thread is waiting for a notify signal on 0x00002b2abb6ccf28. How is that notify meant to be posted to the main thread and is it possible for it to have been posted incorrectly ?
The machine in question is a Dual CPU 3.2GHz 64bit Intel box.
From the thread dump looks like this may be in the J2EE component. Reassigning...

I got past this problem by not specifying "-clean" when starting up eclipse. I must have tried to start it with -clean at least 5 times and then forcefully had to kill it off.
When I ran Eclipse without -clean it did not appear to lockup and I got a workbench first time.

I think this was probably fixed when I fixed bug 151448 by refactoring the J2EEComponentClasspath container to 1. no longer listen for EMF events (the main thread is stuck on this path) and 2. to use Jobs to perform the actual update (again the main thread is stuck on this path.

bug.short_desc: Schema editor doesn't handle elements with attributes and body content

long_desc.thetext:
The extension point schema editor does not support schema elements that contain both body content and attributes. I did most of my testing in 3.2 but it appears to behave this way in 3.1.2 as well.
To reproduce:
Create a new plug-in project named "foo". Add an extension point named "foo", with id and name both "foo". In the schema editor, click "New Element", and save the file. Note that the DTD approximation for the element is (#PCDATA). Click the "foo.exsd" tab and note that the exsd contains a new element described as follows:
<element name="new_element1" type="string"> </element>
Now, click back on the "Definition" tab, select the new element, and click New Attribute. Note that the DTD approximation is now EMPTY. The exsd now looks like this:
<element name="new_element1"> <complexType> <attribute name="new_attribute1" type="string"> <annotation> <documentation>
</documentation> </annotation> </attribute> </complexType> </element>
So, creating the attribute caused the element to no longer have a content type. But this seems incorrect; certainly XML schema supports the idea that an element may have both content and attributes.
The following hand-written schema is properly read by the platform at runtime, although it is not supported by the GUI schema editor (and any edits from there cause it to be destroyed), and it is not supported by the PDE's HTML schema help generator:
<element name="new_element1"> <annotation> <documentation> Description of the element's body content </documentation> </annotation> <complexType> <simpleContent> <extension base="string"> <attribute name="new_attribute1" type="string"> <annotation> <documentation> Description of the attribute </documentation> </annotation> </attribute> </extension> </simpleContent> </complexType> </element>

bug.short_desc: UI improvement of the hyperlink builder

long_desc.thetext:
When user try to create a drill thru hyper link, the hyper link builder will ask user to create an expression that can be evaluated to the string of the target bookmark.
This UI is not user friendly, since it is difficult to know what are the bookmarks are in the target report.
It will make it easer that by default the UI shows the terget report's book marks list, and user can simply select the bookmark as a static string expression.
Only when user want to create dynamic hyper link, the UI will let user click on the "..." to invoke the expression builder.
please see the "internal bookmark UI" it does what is described above.

Apparently, when the target report has book mark defined, the hyper link build already shows the list in version 2.1.0.
The enhancement is only needed when there is no book mark or toc defined in the target report. In such case, UI should not ask user to creat target book marks, because the target report has no book mark defined. There is no point of define any book mark exprssion in the link since it will not match anything.
step3 in drill thru hyper link builder should be disabled when the target report does not have bookmark defined. and if the user click on the radio box in step 2 to select TOC, step3 should be disable if there is no TOC entry in the target report.

(In reply to comment #1) > Apparently, when the target report has book mark defined, the hyper link build > already shows the list in version 2.1.0. > The enhancement is only needed when there is no book mark or toc defined in the > target report. In such case, UI should not ask user to creat target book > marks, because the target report has no book mark defined. There is no point of > define any book mark exprssion in the link since it will not match anything. > step3 in drill thru hyper link builder should be disabled when the target > report does not have bookmark defined. and if the user click on the radio box > in step 2 to select TOC, step3 should be disable if there is no TOC entry in > the target report.
An alternative solution is to always have a value of "---" in the bookmark or TOC selection list. If the report doesn't have a bookmark or TOC, "---" will be the only value in the list. And if user selects "---", the link will not include bookmark or TOC in its URL.
Fixed it. Added a value of "---" into the bookmark and TOC selection list, and always display it in the drop down list. If user selects "---", set the link not include bookmark and TOC.

bug.short_desc: [j2ee properties] "duplicate project in classpath" after eclipse start

long_desc.thetext:
wtp 1.5 and 1.5.1. In my dynamic web project with lots of dependencies I noticed the following. I exit Eclipse with a project that has zero errors. I start eclipse again and get a "duplicate project in classpath" error on my dynamic web project. - removing the project from the Java Build Path fixes the error, but often will result in "class not found" errors at an appearently random time later on. - Another way to fix is to leave the project as-is and do a clean all!? This repeats ad infinitum.
I have the idea that the projects added with the J2EE Module Dependencies page are (sometimes) added to the project classpath and that this causes this problem..

When you get the duplicate project on classpath error my guess is one off the projects is being picked up from a direct project classpath dependency, and the other from the Web App Libraries Container. Is this correct? Or is the second one coming from the EAR Libraries container (the second container should only be present if your web project is in an EAR)

If items in the DEPLOYMENT path are added to the classpath also this could well be. But I fail to see why this would be so.. It is still strange that just a clean all would "fix" the error even though both j2ee deps and build deps are not changed.

Is this an actual bug and/or is there any plan to fix?
I am seeing what appears to be the same problem in WTP 1.5.5 / RAD 7.0.0.4.
The "Build path contains duplicate entry.." error is reported when projects are referenced in the MANIFEST.MF (for a J2EE module) AND via the .classpath. I have also seen where these errors go away when a clean is performed, but they usually return when the eclipse workbench is relaunched.

The duplicate entries problem is being tracked by bug 183297.
The correct approach for classpath entries being duplicated by the EAR Libraries classpath container is to remove the single entry being duplicated from the .classpath.
If this is not possible, then you might also consider simply removing the EAR Libraries classpath container from the project all together. Doing so, however, will mean you are opting out of having WTP manage the MANIFEST.MF specified classpath and you will need manage all workspace classpaths. This method is not recommended and should only be used as a last resort.
There have also been numerous bug fixes since 1.5.1 related to this classpath container which should help the "- removing the project from the Java Build Path fixes the error, but often will result in "class not found" errors at an appearently random time later on." problem.

2. private resources: to display resources that are in the current BIRT report design project.

Hit commit button too quick:
The priviate category will appear in BIRT IDE designer only. For RCP designer, it can use shared BIRT resource only.

I suggest that we do not introduce the public and private lib resource lib concept for now. since it is new deployment concept that needs model and engine support in addition to UI change. For the usage that wenbin mention for Actuate BIRT, BIRT already supports it, it can create a resource fragment for the pre-build libs and resource, in stead of using the resource folder.
In short, I think following change will work that
(1) if the user preference of resource folder is null, set the resource folder to be the project folder on desktop. (2) lib explorer should use the same alg as model's resource locator to show libraries in the resource folder AND the resource fragments. (3) default BIRT install can leave the user preference of resource folder to be null. Built-in resources shall use resource fragment.

(In reply to comment #32) > I patched the JDT in version M20060823-1200 to remove the cleanup call on line > 680 of CompilationUnitResolver but still get the NPE.
Are you certain that the patch took effect, ie, that you were running the patched code? Eg, if you put a breakpoint in your patched code, does it get hit, and does it indeed avoid the call to cleanUp()?
> BTW, what exactly does [batch mode] mean? It would be nice to > see the JDT-APT project page updated to explain this and other features of the > project in general.
Please feel free to enter an enhancement request.
Batch mode is aimed at processors that assume they are running under Sun apt in command-line mode and thus assume that getSpecifiedTypeDeclarations() will return all types on the command line, that their processor will only get called a certain number of times (once per round), and so forth. For instance, we've seen processors that count the number of times that process() is called and do things differently depending on which round it is. Obviously in the context of an IDE that breaks. So in batch mode, we only call process() during a full build, and we try to emulate the apt command-line sequence of operations as closely as possible.

I have just verified that indeed the patched code was being executed by setting breakpoints at various modified locations in the source, as well as observing the output of System.err.println() statements. What confuses me now is that the inner loop that was doing the eager cleanup is never run! That is, the following condition never appears to be true when compiling my code:
(this.requestedSources.size() == 0 && this.requestedKeys.size() == 0)
I'm not sure if this is helpful, but below is the output from a couple of stack trace dumps I inserted in the JDT for the point at which the 'scope' field is set to null for the type that later causes the NPE when it's scope field is dereferenced. I wanted to see if I could learn something about the order in which scopes are defined and used during compilation. At this point, all I can derive is that scopes are being cleaned up too eagerly within some compilation phase. Of course, this was already implied by the proposed fix.

I encountered this very same problem and have just, rather unsatisfyingly, worked around it. I have a ~250kloc project with: no dependancies on any other project, many custom annotations (for run-time bytecode manipulation, not for compile-time annotation processing), and around a hundred errors. I got the NPE in question during the clean build that occurs as soon as you add (here, the first) annotation factory to the build preferences, regardless of whether the annotation processor was called upon. The problem remained, for around four weeks of development (I tried turning annotation processing back on every couple of days as I tired of forgetting to run apt from the command line).
This morning I had some time to play with this --- I'd like to feel good about annotation processing before the next big project push --- so I compile a version of jdt.core from HEAD that checks for (this.scope==null) before the offending line. This gets me an error free build clean, and a successful annotation processor run, although the annotation needing processing is, by this point, only deployed on a handful of classes. My unit tests all run, but I cannot say anything about the general impact of my "patch". By turning DEBUG on in the compiler it appears that I got a null scope on an static inner class that declared no methods or fields or annotations, simply "static public class Bar extends Foo {}". The both the outer and inner classes had no annotations in their superclass structures either.
However, moving back to the stock, unedited jdt.core now also works on the project (both clean builds and "automatic" builds). So, while I've worked around the problem, I no longer have a project that causes the problem to offer to the debugging effort.
I'll, um, let you know if it returns.
With I20060912-0800 (on Mac OSX 9A241e, with Eclipse on 1.5.0_06)
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 156352 ***

bug.short_desc: [discussion] automatically infer interest of newly created tasks

long_desc.thetext:
When new tasks arive it could be convenient to have trained baesian filter that would bring them into interest depends on the specifics of the interest of the particular user.
For instance, I am not that interested in Zest right now... :-)

Maybe this even could include a bayesian spellchecker... ;-)
Sorry, I just couldn't resist it... :-D

The trouble with the spellchecker is who wil train the trainer? So, it is just a matter of good dictionaly, which Eclipse platform is not willing to provide.
However there is a good chance to train the categorisation filter based on bayesian algorithm. So, I am actually very serious here.

I'm needing spel cheking too... it's our bug 103093 blocked by Platform bug 51444, and they're blocked by getting a dictionary they can bundle under the EPL.
I took "bayesian filter" out of the description because there are multiple approaches to making this work. For example, for a repository that was rich in structure (i.e. regular use of bug dependencies), the interest propagation mechanism could be used to infer interest. But bugs.eclipse.org definitely lacks this kind of structure, so the bayesian filter approach could work well.
A secondary issue is how to encode the interest. One way is the context model, but we don't yet have a mechanism for sharing that across developers. Another simple approach could be using the CC field (e.g. so that it shows up in a query of "all reports I'm CC'd on"). Anvik and Murphy have demonstrated a very cool classifier that recommends assignments, and it could be really useful if that approach could be applied to automatically determine CC's: http://www.cs.ubc.ca/~janvik/papers/icse2006/whofix.pdf

bug.short_desc: [1.5][compiler] enum referencing error

long_desc.thetext:
I've seen this problem with several 3.2 pre-releases as well as 3.2 proper:
I have an enum containing about 30-40 members and a static final int. The enum class itself compiles fine. However, *some* other classes that refer to the enum elements don't compile, complaining about entries that can't be resolved. Other values from the same enum class are referenced just fine in the referring class.
The enum elements that fail to get referenced properly are either proper enum members or the public static final int member. I've tried clean builds, but to no avail.
If I build outside of eclipse via jdk 1.5.0_06, everything builds fine. Thus, this is either a JDT bug, or I've got something misconfigured. I know for sure that Eclipse is in 'jdk 1.5' mode. If it wasn't all the template stuff I'm doing wouldn't work either.
Thanks much.
Can you pls provide exact steps to reproduce ? We did address a couple enum issues lately, which will make it into 3.2.1, see early preview at: http://www.eclipse.org/jdt/core/r3.2/index.php#UPDATES

I've tried to reproduce it in isolation, but to no avail. It only fails in the context of our overall system.
Is there any kind of debug logging I can turn on in Eclipse? For example, I could do a 'clean', then turn on some debugging, and then build my project. I could then send you that debug output, which hopefully won't include every line of code in the project! :)
In the past I may have sometimes managed to get past the bug by modifying the enum class to have members in a different order...but I'm not sure.
Sorry I can't give you a test case, but I am very willing to try anything you suggest and to give you any debug info that may help you.

There is no specific trace which would help you here I am afraid.
Can't you attach a project ? Also does problem occur in both clean build and incremental build mode ? Pls check bug 145746, bug 145732 or bug 141810 to see if you recognize something familiar.
Last, did you try the 3.2.1 preview I mentionned earlier, it contains fixes for these issues (and many others), maybe this would address your issues as well.

I just downloaded org.eclipse.jdt.core_3.2.1.jar. I put it in my c:\eclipse\plugins directory and started up Eclipse, but it didn't seem to do anything. I then tried updating c:\eclipse\features\org.eclipse.jdt_3.2.0.v20060609m-F7snq1fxia-Z4XP\feature.xml to declare that it's got version 3.2.1 of the jdt core plugin rather than 3.2.0.v_671. That didn't seem to help either.
I can't give you a project because I can't give you our code...it's proprietary.
Please tell me what I have to do to be sure I'm running with the new jdt. Thanks!

Created an attachment (id=46739) Enum class that compiles, but when referenced doesn't always work.
Some classes that reference this enum's elements fail to compile because they claim that they can't find the enum value.

One of my colleagues and I were talking about this a little while ago, and one thing that struck us is that the bug showed up for only one enum class. All of our other enum classes seem to be referenced fine.
He did some experiments and figured out the critical difference between the "bad" enum class and the other good ones:
the bad one has a non-static method near the end. If he commented out that method definition and re-built, all of the enum reference problems went away (and naturally, those classes trying to call the commented out method now had compile failures).
I tried reproducing this in isolation, but to no avail. I'm hoping that this gives you a direction to look in, however. I just attached our "bad" enum class. Hopefully, you'll be able to do something useful with it.

My colleague did some more experiments and discovered that it's not so much about methods being in the enum class. He said even after removing methods from the enum, at some point in time some consumer classes stopped being able to reference the enum elements. He believes that the act of modifying/saving the enum class made problems go away for a little while, regardless of what change occurred.
We both also have wondered, "What's different about this enum than other enums we use?" This is a bigger enum class than any other that we use in our project, and it's name is BeanName. Is there anything significant about the name of the enum class? Maybe there's an underlying name resolution bug and we're picking up a different BeanName class in the referents.

The enum class that's giving me trouble is BeanName (attached to this bug a few weeks ago). Classes that have trouble referencing enums in BeanName compile fine if BeanName is already compiled (e.g. an incremental build launched when I make a dummy modification of a class the refers to BeanName).
Thanks for the testcase, will look into it. (delay is due to vacation time)
Cannot reproduce on your testcase. Could you attach an example of some referencing file which doesn't work ?
Added EnumTest#test136 (with simple ref to offending BeanName enum).
Removing 3.2.1 tag until further reproduced/assessed.

It seems I can no longer reproduce the issue. I've tried several clean builds, but it never fails as it did before. I suspect that as our code evolved, whatever triggered this bug seems to have stopped.
I suspect there is a race condition between BeanName being built and its consumers. Thus, a dummy modification of one of the consumers and doing an incremental build would make the problem go away because BeanName is already compiled at the time of the incremental build.
Sorry I can't give you more (well, half-sorry. I'm half-relieved that I'm not experiencing the issue any more... but of course some other random change in our code might tickle this again).
Also, I did reproduce the issue on 3.3M1, but there's no way to know if I reproduced it on 3.2.1 since I couldn't find the instructions for how to install the 3.2.1 jdt into my 3.2.0 setup (am I supposed to look at "Getting the sources"? "build notes"?)
Will close it as REMIND, i.e. if you see it again and have better luck finding steps, then pls reopen it.

attachment.desc: Enum class that compiles, but when referenced doesn't always work.

bug.short_desc: [search] Reference search result as tree omits declaring class of binary anonymous

long_desc.thetext:
I20060718-0800
- have org.eclipse.core.resources and org.eclipse.ui.ide available for Java search - search for references to IResource.move(IProjectDescription, int, IProgressMonitor) - set search result view to Show as Tree and Group by Project.
=> There's a search result at: org.eclipse.ui.ide org.eclipse.ui.ide_3.3.0.I200060718-0800.jar org.eclipse.ui.actions new WorkspaceModifyOperation() {...} execute(IProgressMonitor)
Expected: ... org.eclipse.ui.actions MoveProjectAction <= really required performMove(IProject, String, IPath) <= nice to have new WorkspaceModifyOperation() {...} execute(IProgressMonitor)
If you don't want to increase the depth of the tree, at least the label of the anonymous should include the declaring type.

if org.eclipse.ui.ide is in source, the tree looks like: org.eclipse.ui.ide src org.eclipse.ui.actions MoveProjectAction performMove(IProject, String, IPath) new WorkspaceModifyOperation() {...} execute(IProgressMonitor)

Hm, seems to be the same problem as in bug 87165. I don't see a way to get back from an IType for an anonymous binary type to its declaring method or type. getParent() always returns the IClassFile and getDeclaringType() is broken.
Would probably need something like 'IJavaElement getParentInSource()' in IMember which returns the parent as seen in source. AFAIK, it's not possible to extract this information from class files alone without guessing, so this would only work for class files with source.

Yes, seems to be a problem for anonymous classes in binaries. Note: Binary member types are correctly shown inside their parent type.
Question to jdt.core: Anything that can be done here? Maybe show the anonymous classes as member types if the correct parent method can't be evaluated anymore?
In ITypeBinding, there's a method #getDeclaringMethod(). If we could get the same for IType, I guess we could solve the problem.

bug.short_desc: CVS change set of task don't work when task was active between eclipse sessions.

long_desc.thetext: When eclipse is opened and a task was active between eclipse sessions, changed files don't get added to CVS change set of the task unless you turn off and on the task.

I recall seeing this happen a while back, but I can't reproduce it any more. Could you please get the latest dev build, see if you can reproduce it, and if so let me know if you are using the model-based mode, i.e. do you see change sets in Incoming/Outgoing mode or not? http://www.eclipse.org/mylar/doc/faq.php#change-sets

The bug still exists. When eclipse is restarted and I open Synchronize view, it warns me that I should populate it without CVS check or synchronize it. Don't matter what I choose, change set don't appear. Moreover, if I now would work, changes wouldn't be attached to active task when it appear after task deactivating and activating.
And I don't understand what are you talking about in faq. >If you are using the standard mode, Change Sets toolbar button will only appear >if the Synchronize view is in Incoming or Outgoing mode, not in the combined >Incoming/Outgoing mode. This button must be pressed in order for change sets to >appear. For working with CVS two modes are indistinguishable beyond this >limitation. Are first two sentences about CVS or what? Please, make it clear here and in FAQ.

I've updated the FAQ to try and make this more clear. Note the first paragraph:
http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#Change_Set_and_Synchronize_view_troubleshooting
The Change Set UI itself is part of the Eclipse Platform and does leave a lot to be desired. I can not reproduce the problem that you are seeing, but I'm also wondering if this is just the refresh bug that the FAQ entry warns about (which is always reproducible as the Platform bug report indicates). What I suggest you do is put Eclipse into the 'standard' mode recommended in the FAQ. If you're seeing the populate/synchronize message on startup you're not in the 'standard' mode.
If as a part of diagnosing this on your end you have can expand on the current FAQ entry to make it more clear that could be helpful to others.

> I've updated the FAQ to try and make this more clear. Note the first > paragraph: > http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#Change_Set_and_Synchronize_view_troubleshooting Were you updating the page in hurry? It has a wonderful sentence "These modes".
And please remove this or correct, that this is not connected to CVS anyhow, cause I have no this toolbar button for CVS. "If you are using the standard mode, Change Sets toolbar button will only appear if the Synchronize view is in Incoming or Outgoing mode, not in the combined Incoming/Outgoing mode. " Please note I have eclipse 3.2. I just looked at 3.1, it has such toolbar button.
> The Change Set UI itself is part of the Eclipse Platform and does leave a lot > to be desired. I can not reproduce the problem that you are seeing, but I'm > also wondering if this is just the refresh bug that the FAQ entry warns about > (which is always reproducible as the Platform bug report indicates). What I > suggest you do is put Eclipse into the 'standard' mode recommended in the FAQ. > If you're seeing the populate/synchronize message on startup you're not in the > 'standard' mode. The option 'Allow models participate in synchronizations' was turned off. I turn it on and off again, and nothing changed. "Populate/synchronize" message is still exists on restart. Please note I have Eclipse 3.2.
> If as a part of diagnosing this on your end you have can expand on the current > FAQ entry to make it more clear that could be helpful to others. >

Yes I changed the web page in a hurry just before leaving for vacation to attempt to provide some clarification on this problem. I've removed that partial sentence.
As you indicate I did miss a necessary step, and not even restarting Eclipse will force some existing synchronizations into the new mode. The synchronization must be recreated, so I added the following sentence and gave it some bold text. It's really unfortunate how confusing the Eclipse UI is for Change Sets, so if you have any other suggestions on making that FAQ entry more clear please post them.
"If you switch modes you must re-create your synchronization via the "Synchronize..." button available form the first toolbar button on the Synchronize view." http://wiki.eclipse.org/index.php/Mylar_FAQ#Change_Set_and_Synchronize_view_troubleshooting
So is the bug reproducible in the model-based mode?

I just manually verified several scenarios of restoring change sets on startup in both the models and standard mode, and can not reproduce any failures. If you can provide steps to reproduce please reopen.

bug.short_desc: Remove from view doesn't affect commit set

long_desc.thetext:
If I choose to remove files from the synchronization view, the files are still scheduled for commit when I click on Commit outgoing changes. In 3.1, it would only commit the files which are in the sync. view.
Also, if you have two directories, but only want to commit one of them, and you select both the parent and the one directory below, then right click and choose commit, the second dir is also committed.

'Remove From View' has already been fixed in HEAD and the 3.2.1 stream, so you can try it out in an integration build or a maintenance build.

P1 =f1 =f2
If I select P1 and f1 and select commit, all of the files contained in f1 and f2 are committed. Is this correct? If so, then I would say that is the correct behaviour as selecting P1 automatically includes f1 and f2 (this was also the behaviour in 3.1).

bug.short_desc: [CellEditors] Listeners for CellSelections

long_desc.thetext: At the moment there's no API to listen for Cell-based selections on Table/Tree-Viewers.
Created an attachment (id=46627) Adds new Listener API to Listen for CellSelections

Tom, thanks for the patch. One minor comment: CellSelectionEvent should probably have an element field instead of the item field.
More generally, I am not sure what this is for (if it only uses the mouse as a selection source). What is your use case for adding this?

(In reply to comment #2) > Tom, thanks for the patch. One minor comment: CellSelectionEvent should > probably have an element field instead of the item field. > > More generally, I am not sure what this is for (if it only uses the mouse as a > selection source). What is your use case for adding this? >
Yes please see a much better version in in my implementation from Bug 149193.
I think the overall idea becomes clear when you look at my example code from bug 149193. But I think you are often interested which specific cell a user currently entered and as shown in 149193 this could be used to activate CellEditors in a more elegant way than it is now providing informations about the cell-activation (key-strokes,double-click,key-board-selection)

Any comments on this. I'm answering question like "do I know which cell is click once a week" and because we already extract this information for editing I think we could also make it available to the users.

Created an attachment (id=54784) A first patch to bring back this feature
This patch adds the API and modifies AbstractViewerEditor to deal directly with ViewerCell instead of recollecting the information already known because of the CellSelection. The current implementation only provides cell selections based upon Mouse-Actions but extending the whole system to allow keyboard navigation and selection should be possible. The given patch provides a first step.
Boris think this could be our next topic to work on because I modified API methods from AbstractViewerEditor I think we should put this in directly after TableViewer-Independency is done (before TreeViewer-Independency)
Created an attachment (id=54904) And make it reapplyable to HEAD

Boris wanted me to explain the great picture for this new feature so here it is. For me cell-selection events are fired under the following circumstances: - click on cell - double click on cell - keystrokes defined using something like ColumnViewer#setCellSelectionStrokes(KeyStroke[]) (maybe we should support standard strokes like SPACE, RETURN using constants)
Based upon this information I think EditingSupport will get a new API function like EditingSupport#isEditorActivationEvent(CellSelectionEvent) which will decide if an editor for the currently selected cell is started.
CellSelection based on Mouse-Events is nearly ready if this patch goes in CVS but I haven't implemented it in this patch because this bug only talks about the ground work providing all those new functionalities. The reall work on editor activation customization needs to be done in bug #151295.
Let's now go to keyboard-activation. To make this happen the first thing we need to support is keyboard navigation inside table/tree's. To accomplish this we need to track the currently selected cell ourselfs by hooking into the keyboard events(Boris could you once more provide the link you sent me while chating I've somehow lost it).
We need to provide a methods in CellLabelProvider which deals with layouting the currently selected cell and maybe turn of the system selection using ownerdraw like shown in one of the SWT-Snippets. The rest is easy if the SelectionEvent is fired because one of the defined key-strokes is detected EditingSupport#isEditorActivationEvent(CellSelectionEvent) is checked and the editor in the cell is activated. To support keyboard activation I have no test-code until now but I only wanted to present the great picture to all of you.
I'd love to get some comments from all of you interested in this for my understanding really very important feature for Datacentric-Editing-Applications based upon JFace-Viewers.
Created an attachment (id=55407) patch that applies to HEAD
Created an attachment (id=55408) One more change to start customization of editor activation

Although technically not 100% correct I added this bug as blocker for bug #167509 because when we decide to integrate this patch AbstractViewerEditor works with ViewerCell and it would be much more natural pass this information along to the editing support.

bug.short_desc: Support for dynamic columns

long_desc.thetext:
Does BIRT currently supports Dynamic columns? I am using scripted datasource, since the JdbcDataSource is too static. (We need to specify connection related params statically. In my case, the connection related parameter differs for each customer).
From the DB, i can receive any number of columns depending on the customer. I just want to display this data using BIRT.
Is this feature already present or is a valid enhancement?

The features you requested are already in BIRT. (1) Dynamic JDBC connection properties. You can use either Property Binding or Scripting feature to override static connection properties defined in the data source at runtime. Please search the BIRT Newsgroup for usage examples - this is one of the more commonly discussed topics there.
(2) Dynamic columns. I am not certain what your requirements are here. If the requirement is simply to generate a dynamic SQL that selects columns based on user input, you can again use either property binding or scripting to override the queryText of the data set. If however you need to manipulate the table/list structure which present the data set data at runtime (such as adding/removing a table column), you will need to use the Design Engine API to modify the report design prior to executing them.
If your requirements are not met by any of these approaches, please reopen this Bugzilla and describe your use cases in detail. A few examples will greatly help us understand exactly what you need.

bug.short_desc: [Dialogs] DCR: provide infrastructure to control 'Don't show this dialog again'

long_desc.thetext:
3.2
Some dialogs offer a 'Don't show this dialog again' checkbox. We want to provide a possibility to enable these dialogs again, for example if a user changed its mind.
In JDT we added a control on the 'Java' preference page. I just saw that WTP has the same on 'Web Services / Popup Dialog Selection'
It seems to me that this would better be offered by platform:
General / Dialogs
Press 'Clear' to clear the 'do not show again' setting and show the hidden dialog again.
Tree top node compenent 'Java' 'Web Sercices' child nodes names of hidden dialogs
Buttons: Clear, Clear All
Needs an extension point for dialog ID/ description and API to ask or set the 'hide' state of a dialog. (Or a special instance of a dialog, OptionalDialog)

This would need preference support in General>Dialogs and possibly in JFace.
Moving to Susan for comment.
PW

The pref page itself sounds pretty simple. As Martin says, we would need an extension point for naming the dialog and its category, and for specifying the class for setting the hide option (or specify the pref store/key where it should be set).
In the dialog framework, we would probably want to provide some infrastructure for showing the "do not show again" checkbox, as well as code in the open sequence to check the value. This support would need to be instance-based (not requiring overrides in the dialog framework), so that clients of generic dialogs like SelectionDialogs can treat their different uses as separate dialogs.
This all seems doable, just needs to be prioritized.
+1 Platform Text could also use this.
changing prio and status per platform ui bug guidelines

bug.short_desc: Group projects hierarchically

long_desc.thetext:
Hi all, I have many projects in my workspace, where about 4-5 projects each make up one 'large overall project' so to speak. It would be great if projects could be organised hierarchically in the project navigation view (the semantics is that I would like to hide all alien projects than the one I am currently working on).
So for example (as it is now): +Project A +Project B +Project C +Project D +Project E
but actually project X _is_ projects A and B, and project Y _is_ projects C, D and E (this is not a technological thing but an organisational one). So if I'm working on project X, I want to hide project Y. And not in the sense of a "closed project" as it is now but hidden in a tree like structure.
So the view would be:
+Project X +-Project A +-Project B +Project Y (hide here) +-Project D (-> hidden) +-Project E (-> hidden) +-Project F (-> hidden)
I know that I can cross-reference projects, but I just want a visual treat because I always lose track of corresponding projects.
Thank you for consideration, Mario
You can define working sets that I believe do exactly what you're looking for. In the Package Explorer, hit the little "down triangle" and you'll see some options concerning working sets.
You also get the hierarchy if you change the top level elements to "Working Sets" there. However, I would love to see that in the navigator too together with a quick filter. ;)

bug.short_desc: Support for multiple location assignments should be added

long_desc.thetext: During the process of Eclipse update the page "Installation" allows selective assignments of the new components (aka features) to different install locations. This ends up in individual feature assignments to another loaction, if that differs from the default value, which is a pain given a notable number of new features if the default location differs from the wanted one. Furtheron the list of "features to install" does not support multiple selections. I strongly suggest the support of a multiple-selection list, which allows one-step assignments of a bunch of features to a given install location

bug.short_desc: [performance] getVMInstallType(...) and saveVMConfiguration() are expensive

long_desc.thetext:
The two methods JavaRuntime.getVMInstallType(...) and JavaRuntime.saveVMConfiguration() are expensive operations. On my machine they took 1125 ms and 391 ms respectively.
I noticed this problem when using WTP (Web Tools Project) with a lot of server runtimes (each of which contributed their own JVM).
Moving to JDT Debug.

I don't see a lot of problems here. Is there any more information on how these methods are used?
getVMInstallType(...) might be slow the first time it is called (it has to lazily load VM install types), but should be fast after that.
saveVMConfiguration() saves the VM settings and notifies listeners of adde/removed VMs. This can effect classpaths, etc. - but I need to know more about the specific use case that is slow.
Marking as REMIND for more input. I don't have a use case/scenario where this is a real problem.
Reopening to close

Haven't heard from the original reporter for over half a year. Multiple requests for more information. No indication that this is a significant performance issue.
Marking as INVALID.

I guess most people click finish on first page right away. There is no need to create and initialize all the UI stuff for the second page.

This can't be solved without another refactoring pass. The new JavaProjectWizard uses the second page to create the project, the second page uses the BuildPathBlock to configure the project, and this only works at the moment with all the UI stuff created and initialized...
Not much I can do here...
